channel.title: Bloomberg Economics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: RBA Poised for Back-to-Back Rate Cuts as Tariffs Darken Outlook
item.description: Australia’s central bank is set to deliver its first back-to-back interest-rates cuts in six years, stepping up its easing cycle as inflation pressures cool and US trade policies threaten a fragile global outlook.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Sydney Harbour and the skyline of the central business district (CBD) in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday, April 29, 2025. Australian capital city house prices continue to rise, and hotly anticipated interest rate cuts later this year could add further fuel to the fire, leaving some buyers and renters struggling to keep roofs over their heads.

item.title: Trump’s Tariff Date Arrives After a 90-Day Rollercoaster
item.description: The world economy, beset with uncertainty for three months over Donald Trump’s on-again-off-again tariffs, is about to get more clarity as the US president’s deadline for trade deals arrives on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a signing ceremony for the One Big Beautiful Bill Act on the South Lawn of the White House on July 4. Photographer: Bonnie Cash/UPI

item.title: Thailand to Offer US More Trade Concessions to Avert 36% Tariff
item.description: Thailand is making a last-ditch effort to avert a punitive 36% export levy threatened by the Trump administration with offers of greater market access for US farm and industrial goods, along with increased purchases of energy and Boeing jets.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes next to shipping containers at the Bangkok Port in Bangkok, Thailand, Sunday, Jan. 28, 2024. Thailand is scheduled to announce export figures on Jan. 31.

item.title: French Companies Seek to Invest $947 Million in Malaysia
item.description: Several French companies seek to invest a total of 4 billion ringgit ($947 million) in Malaysia after a trade delegation led by Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim met with 40 industry representatives in France on Friday, according to Malaysia’s Ministry of Investment, Trade and Industry.
item.dc:creator: Netty Idayu Ismail

media:content.media:description: A Rapid KL train travels along an elevated track in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on Sunday, Jan. 14. 2024. Malaysia is scheduled to release it's annual gross domestic product (GDP) figures on Jan. 19. Photographer: Richard Humphries/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea Seeks US Trade Deadline Extension as Tariffs Loom
item.description: South Korean and US trade officials have discussed extending the July 9 deadline for trade deals in a last-minute bid to avert sweeping tariffs from President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: A worker prepares to unload General Motors Co. (GM) Buick vehicles on a trailer truck at the Port of Incheon in Incheon, South Korea, on Tuesday, May 20, 2025. Nearly half of the vehicles GM sold in the US last year — 1.23 million autos — were built abroad, according to researcher GlobalData.

item.title: France Urges Tariff Barriers to Stop China From Killing Industry
item.description: French Finance Minister Eric Lombard said Europe must shore up its tariff barriers to counter Chinese imports that risk harming the continent’s industrial economy.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin, Francois De Beaupuy

media:content.media:description: A steel storage warehouse in Hangzhou, China, on Friday, Feb. 7, 2025. Metals investors are weighing the prospect of worsening international trading conditions after the Trump administration slapped tariffs on China and threatened other countries including Canada and Mexico.

item.title: Japan Top Trade Negotiator Holds Two Phone Meetings With Lutnick
item.description: Japan’s chief trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa held two phone meetings with US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick to discuss tariffs as a July 9 deadline for higher levies nears.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa, Japan's economic revitalization minster, speaks to members of the media at the Japanese embassy in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, June 6, 2025. Japan and the US have begun the latest round of trade negotiations, with media reports suggesting Tokyo’s delegation is trying to win a reprieve from the tariffs by pledging to make more cars in the US and enhancing cooperation on rare earths.

item.title: ECB’s Makhlouf Says Euro Not Ready to Challenge Dollar’s Role
item.description: The euro cannot quickly supplant the dollar as the anchor of the world’s financial system as countries using it still have far to go in their financial and economic integration, European Central Bank Governing Council member Gabriel Makhlouf said.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: A euro symbol on a sign outside the headquarters of the European Central Bank (ECB) in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, March 6, 2025. The European Central Bank is about to lower interest rates for the sixth time since June, though a volatile economic backdrop is sowing divisions over where to take borrowing costs from here. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Charting the Global Economy: US Jobs Data Eases Pressure on Fed
item.description: Fresh US jobs figures took pressure off the Federal Reserve to consider an interest-rate cut later this month, likely leaving the central bank on hold at least until the fall.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle

media:content.media:description: Recruiters and job seekers speak during a job fair hosted by the Cook County government to support federal workers in Chicago, Illinois, US, on Thursday, June 26, 2025. Thousands of private government consultants laid off during the Trump administration's cost-cutting crusade are increasingly flooding a shrinking labor market.

item.title: Emily Sundberg on How Nobody Is Coming to Save Gen Z
item.description: What today's young people actually think about money.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Emily Sundberg, author of the Feed Me newsletter, speaks on stage at a live taping of the Odd Lots podcast in New York City, on Thursday, June 26, 2025.

item.title: Butter’s Global Price Surge Hits Croissants and Kitchens Alike
item.description: At the Mamiche bakeries in the 9th and 10th arrondissements of Paris, their famous pains au chocolat and croissants depend on an essential but increasingly scarce ingredient — butter.
item.dc:creator: Celia Bergin, Ben Westcott

media:content.media:description: A pastry chef prepares croissants for sale at a Bakehouse bakery in the Causeway Bay area of Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, July 25, 2024. Bakery chain Bakehouse opened its account on lifestyle app Xiaohongshu after mainland Chinese users raved about its egg tarts — an iconic Hong Kong dessert — on the social media platform.

item.title: Mozambique Weighs Asking China to Rework Debt, President Says
item.description: Cash-strapped Mozambique is open to asking China to restructure the $1.4 billion it owes its biggest bilateral creditor, President Daniel Chapo said.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro, Matthew Hill

item.title: Vietnam’s Growth Surges as Buyers Race to Beat Trump Tariffs
item.description: Vietnam’s growth accelerated in the second quarter as foreign buyers raced to avoid threatened tariffs of as much as 46% on sales to the US.
item.dc:creator: Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen

media:content.media:description: Motorcyclists and trucks in Binh Duong City, Binh Duong Province, Vietnam, on Thursday, April 10, 2025. With almost half of the $34.5 billion of goods exported out of Binh Duong last year shipped to the US, the region is especially vulnerable to tariff shocks. Photographer: Linh Pham/Bloomberg

item.title: Starmer Has Nowhere to Go, Stuck Between Rebels and Bond Market
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer is caught between a political rebellion and a jittery bond market.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Philip Aldrick, Greg Ritchie

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, right, and Rachel Reeves in London on July 3. Photographer: Jack Hill/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: South Korea Passes Extra Budget Before Tariff Deadline
item.description: South Korea’s parliament and cabinet approved a 31.8 trillion won ($23.3 billion) extra budget as new President Lee Jae Myung seeks to revive an economy struggling with weak consumption and mounting trade risks from US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

item.title: Vietnam Gains Edge With Early Trump Deal, US Group Head Says
item.description: Vietnam’s race to secure a trade deal with the Trump administration, even if the details aren’t clear, gives the Southeast Asian country an advantage over regional rivals, according to Ted Osius, president of the US-Asean Business Council.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Stevens, Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen
